What did early Canadian farmers eat?

A Questionnaire

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Arthur J. Wheeler
Address: Bank End, Sask.
Birthplace: Tarrant, Surrey, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? October 23rd, 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? October 23rd, 1906
Where had you been living before that? Portage la Prairie, Manitoba
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
How far was it to your nearest store? 4½ miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly, once or twice monthly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, oatmeal, brown sugar, syrup, flour, baking powder, lard, eggs, egg powder

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Dominion
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? Yorkton
What year? 1906
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 80¢
What other grain products did you use? Breakfast cereal, orange meal, cornmeal
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? With a Roger's roller mill
Wheeler, Arthur J.
Bank End, 1906

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, but remember a neighbour who was. With no flour in the house for weeks he reduced to grinding barley in a coffee mill for porridge, and also for making biscuits. Plenty of milk & cream saved the situation.

In the spring of 1949, my brother and I barely had time to finish seeding before school was out, and on the 15th June we hitched our little syrup can, ate the last piece of bannock, and headed for Strachan siding on foot, looking for work.

No money in our pockets, borrowed a dollar from a neighbour on the way. Arrived at Strachan siding, slept in a box car on the way. Next day pulled out then crawled into a culvert, left a thunderstorm washed us out, then to Purnell, where we got breakfasts walked most of the way to Nelsonia and back to Raymore before we struck work. Our only meals were dinner, two breakfasts.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

In 1906 our nearest supply was at Sheho, 45 miles or so. I purchased my first groceries and household equipment from Leon Beck, Sheho on Oct 18th, 1906. I was paid by check. I started caching on Oct 28th in a log stack which was not covered or plastered. Made bed inside and claims out of poplar level on rafters. In a month, I purchased a quarter of beef from a neighbour, $28.00 for $8.30.

Nov 18th, 1907 went to Sheho with a neighbour, own wagon. Owen's names were Bill, Ed, and Terry who both all start out possible driven without lines. Camped out on the trail bought enough supplies to last but a short time. Underestimated tobacco, so fell back on Wiley's book. Lessons lost, if which I had plenty. Piled the wagons high and hung pots and pans outside the wagon box, and started for home arriving at about noon of Nov 21st. Later on, a farmer set up a store at Round Plains, 10 miles away. A neighbour of mine, Alf Chappell, had occasion to go there one day in the summer.

In 1906 our nearest supply was at Sheshatshiu, 45 miles by boat.

Purchased my first groceries and baseball stuff from 
Jerr 15¢. All stores on 18¢. 28¢. In a big island. Bread was not 
delivered or delivered, made but late and cheap at 3¢/pound 
local or imported. So a month later purchased a greater quantity 
of a regular size. $2.80

Nov. 18th-1907 wrote to Sheshatshiu with a new address 
and name. Also bought bread and sugar who lost all their 
cuts possible. During winter time camped out on the beach 
trough enough supplies to last until spring. Had some 
lettuce so full each on stock food. Season late. Also 
had plenty of meat. Also had some potatoes. Also 
abundant fish within five and fifteen miles away. Also 
money of about $10.

Round Peary 10 m. by away. A northern summer day choppers 
had occurred to go there one day at this distance.
being out of supplies, so he hauled up his cover, let the stove heat in which he placed two chairs so that he and wife Ruby could ride in comfort, on the way home into town and grocers. But even worse was up if a hole spread a story, covered with mosquito and blankets they made a bed here and there slumped but the water was up to their backs and despite all prayers and illusory refusal to budge for two hours, another among accident or temporary supplies was when a neighbor came along with a two wheeled cart and lost a notion he would like to buy a pig, said he could have it alive if it was turned up, and give a little trouble getting a stick branch to stand the pig was placed between his legs, hit around without the branch so on the dead run across country and it never stopped short of home, but left the cold sitting in a deep pool, under the pig between Henry Smith's legs in 15 ft. of water.

Another neighbor of mine, Jack McWhirter, a Scots bachelor, had two shocks at the edge of a river, on the bottom of which a spring ran all winter, rabbits came plentifully, Jack had one spot he could get be seen dead in sheepskin coat sitting on a armchair, with a 32 rifle, pots rolled at the spring, by the shocks a rope was stretched between two poplars, on which he always sat relaxed, whenever a neighbor passed he was bound to take a dozen. Good memories.

A bachelor diet in those days consisted chiefly of game, beef & pork occasionally, hammock (no bread) syrup pones and not eating all pancakes varied by dumplings.

One winter a bachelor gave a big party to 10 or 12 bachelors, after cards in the house served up supper which consisted of a huge plum pudding, nothing done but there was plenty for everyone.

She, after mentioned old Chappie was an old country cabinet maker and every new to farming had difficulty the first year, in growing potatoes. Between the days two low trenches 18 inches deep on each side of the first plot to see just clear, planted his potatoes and as they grew filled in the trench, expecting a wonderful crop he was truly disappointed when he had to dig and dig with no results.

I remember an old country family who used difficulty in making bread on their first attempt the girls put a box of yeast cakes in boiling water, some of the loaves were nailed in the barn door, and smeared all over the woodpokes, making no impression.
